title: Synthetic Recap
body:
TORONTO (AP) — The record books will show the final score: Raptors 100, Bullets 94. But the history made in this 1997 clash will forever bear a single, monumental name: Damon Stoudamire.

In a performance for the ages, Stoudamire erupted for a career-high and franchise-record 54 points, single-handedly dismantling the Washington Bullets in a virtuoso display of offensive firepower. “Mighty Mouse” was colossal, carrying the Raptors on his back and delivering a signature moment for the young expansion franchise.

From the opening tip, Stoudamire was in a different stratosphere. He attacked the rim with fearless abandon, pulled up from anywhere on the court, and poured in baskets with a stunning combination of speed and precision. The Bullets, helpless to contain him, could only watch as the 5-foot-10 dynamo authored one of the most spectacular scoring nights the league had witnessed.

While Stoudamire’s historic 54 points—a staggering figure that dwarfed the output of entire quarters—dominated the narrative, he was not entirely alone. Doug Christie provided crucial support with 17 points, and Popeye Jones controlled the glass with 14 rebounds. But this night was a solo concerto. Tracy Murray led the Bullets with 21 points, a valiant effort that was simply rendered a footnote in the face of Stoudamire’s onslaught.

In the end, the final margin was a mere six points, but the story was never in doubt. It was the night a Raptor soared into the record books, a one-man offensive explosion that secured a win and cemented a legacy. Toronto didn’t just get a victory; it witnessed immortality.
